comment_text: All that which is time bound is unreal
After all the warnings, pointing this out may be the thing that finally gets people serious.

My grandfather owned a coffee plantation in a specialty region in southeastern Brazil. Highlands with wet subtropical climate.
Frost was for decades the biggest threat to coffee farmers in the region. In the past 20 years though reduced rainfall and pests brought by warmer temperatures, made profits shrink to the point cultivation became unviable.
There’s hardly any coffee farming in that region anymore…

I think coffee already tastes worse than a 2-3 decades ago.  🤷.  Old Maxwell house growing up used to taste better IMO than half the coffee sold today in markets.  Now, not so.  Everyone always seems to talk about “future” climate change, when it’s already happened and happening.
Grow coffee in specialized greenhouses.
As if coffee is the thing we'll worry about during floods, hurricanes, tornados, earthquakes, volcanic activity...  Clean water might become the issue, as it is in some places already.

Hi. Robusta coffee even has a rougher flavor. But it does contain a little more caffeine, which a lot of people appreciate.
The problem is that it also contains nephrotoxic compounds, which are harmful to the kidneys. Here in Brazil there is even legislation, limiting the robusta content in common coffee powder to 15%, I guess. But they forgot to provide the inspection with the technical means for the work and the law is almost not enforced.
Gourmet coffees can only contain robusta if this is expressly mentioned on the package.
Anyway, in this more demanding and profitable niche, counterfeiting is rarer.
Hopefully, a way out is found, with the preservation of the diversity of the other species of Coffea. I hate robusta!...

As one who used to do coffee tasting as part of my job, I can say that it would find it very difficult to identify the altitudes that coffees are grown at, in any specific altitude, though it is generally possible to know the usual altitudes coffee is grown in any specific country. In the Americas, the best coffees are grown to the west of the Cordilleras. Thus coffee grown on the western slopes of Mexico are significantly better than those grown on the eastern slopes.
The Americas are known for growing arabica coffee, exclusively at the time when I sat at the tasting table. Whether it is the same today I cannot say. Arabica coffees are sold in two forms- processed and unprocessed. The process is called fermentation but has nothing to do with alcohol. It is a natural process. All the best coffees are processed. Of all the "fermented" coffees, Kenyan and Colombian are clearly superior. Of the others, Costa Rican is most consistently the best. Hawaiian and Jamaican Blue Mountain are generally equivalent to the Central American coffees, but the Centrals are a whole lot cheaper.
Coffee tasting is different from wine tasting and has a mostly different set of terms. Amateur tasters usually use wine tasting terms which are not helpful and misleading, sometimes amusing. If you have an interest in coffee tasting I will be glad to respond.

Hey Sci Show, here is a sorta related question for your crack research team. Since I was kid I have noticed a strange phenomenon with a ceramic mug  filled with freshly made hot chocolate (the kind made from mixing powder with hot water).  If you stir the mixture up and then tap the mug repeatedly with a spoon after the hot water is added , you will often hear the pitch of the sound rise higher and higher over the space of about half a minute, at which time it stops changing. At first I thought that this was because the mug was heating up and this somehow affected its natural frequency  or speed of sound transmission. But, if that were the case, the same would presumably happen with any hot liquid added to the mug - coffee, tea , hot water etc. Yet none of these other liquids seem to to produce the same effect, only hot chocolate.  Maybe it’s related to the ingredients more than the temperature?  What gives? Inquiring minds want to know!

I got a recipe for you.

Robusta beans
Roasted to the first crack (the "light city" or "New England" roast, about as light as it can be without tasting like lawn clippings)
Ground to an espresso grind
Then brewed with a pour-over or in an automatic drip machine; you want maximum contact between water and bean as the water percolates through the coffee.

I call it "Vault 87", because the maximized caffeine from all of the above methods will make you feel like a super mutant.

Anyone who is into coffee enough to be able to taste differences between various coffees already knows that there's a lot of things that go into what makes coffee taste different. From what region within a given country a bean is grown, how much rain they got that growing season, the temperature variation, etc., etc., etc., and that's before getting to all the different things that humans do to the beans AFTER they get picked. EVERYTHING impacts the flavor of the coffee. And no, coffee is NOT going to disappear. it's too staple a crop for humanity for it to be allowed to disappear, it'll just be grown in different places than is traditional.

I would really like to see an honest, open-minded analysis of how the current warm period compares to the Roman and Medieval warm periods. The only comparisons I hear from mainline science communicators start with a CO2-based conclusion and go backwards from there. As a student of history, I know that the current climate isn't particularly unusual. In fact there's some evidence that the Medieval warm period came on as suddenly as the current one, and that was long before we were belching out CO2. And even now CO2 accounts for only about 0.04% of the atmosphere, which seems too small to have the supposed effects, especially when compared to much stronger greenhouse gasses at higher concentration (like, say, water vapor).

Anyway...I know the hard-core "deniers" won't be convinced of anything...nor will the hard-core "warmists"...but there are still some of us who see a lot of holes in the fear-mongering narrative, but are still at least somewhat concerned about what's going on and are seeking honest answers.
